newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israeli bonds end higher after CPI release.
newsitem.headline: Israeli bonds end higher after CPI release.

text.p: Israeli bonds rose on Sunday in response to the October consumer price index (CPI), which was released Friday and rose a relatively moderate 0.8 percent, traders said.
* Unlinked government bonds (Gilon - issued for four years): +0.07 pct to 169.45.
* Bank of Israel short-term Makam bills: +0.14 pct to 160.36
Volume was low at 127 million shekels as prices rose across the board.

"Unlinked bonds rose because investors are now predicting that annual inflation will be around 11 percent," said a trader at Israel Discount Bank. "With yields of 15.5 percent these bonds are very attractive."
Makams also rose. "Yields of 15.2 percent are still attractive," Elisha Rosenfeld of Lehava Investments said. But the Discount trader noted that Makams usually rise after the weekend.

In general the market was stronger. "There are no sellers and prices rose across the board," Rosenfeld said. "Inflation-linked bonds continued to rise, but today short- and medium-term bonds posted nice gains as well as the long bonds."
The Discount trader said demand for CPI-linked bonds was focused on the variable-interest Kfir because investors are expecting yields to rise in the near future.
Dollar-linked bonds rose for the first time in a week, following a 0.35 percent decline last week.
Note: Makams are zero-coupon unlinked certificates with durations of three months to one year. The Bank of Israel issues Makams to absorb liquidity.
